author: pk910
content:
How would the mainnet recover from such a situation if happening post merge?
There are currently only about 15% attestations for new bocks.. 
Does the chain just stay "unfinalized" forever for that time period and finalization continues on new blocks once enough validators are available again?

author: bridge-bot
content: <dannyryan> A quadratic leak occurs over some period in which offline vals leak enough such that online vals are the majority and finalize. This assuming no manual intervention or resolution of partition

author: bridge-bot
content: <dannyryan> Also, I believe there is a chain with more participation but the explorer isnt following it

author: galaxybloom.
content: Are there any legal or regulatory concerns for devs or the EF around manual intervention / resolution of a partition?

author: pk910
content: hmm but that implies that both chains (after such a fork) can be reaching finalization again after some time and "look valid"?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<dannyryan> Yes. This takes almost 3 weeks 
We expect that anything that can be resolved can be done so in 2 weeks max

author: bridge-bot
content:
<dannyryan> Some things that cannot be resolved by devs/community
* global network partition lasting 3 weeks
* government perpetual takedown of some large percentage of validators

author: bridge-bot
content: <dannyryan> Users ultimately decide what code to run. There are countless reasons a partition might occur. Some are likely simple -- one client not to spec. Some might be more complex

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Some more insights on the kintsugi issues: https://twitter.com/vdWijden/status/1479945793893277698
TLDR: The blockexplorer wasn't updated and Teku nodes had the same issue in their optimistic sync as LH (interpreting errors in execute payload not as invalid payloads)

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: And since the payloads were actually correct blocks, we could fetch them from the network and execute them without problems
